Finite strain theory

In continuum mechanics, the finite strain theory—also called large strain theory, or large deformation theory—deals with deformations in which strains and/or rotations are large enough to invalidate assumptions inherent in infinitesimal strain theory. In this case, the undeformed and deformed configurations of the continuum are significantly different, requiring a clear distinction between them. This is commonly the case with elastomers, plastically deforming materials and other fluids and biological soft tissue.

Displacement field

The displacement of a body has two components: a rigid-body displacement and a deformation.
  • A rigid-body displacement consists of a translation and rotation of the body without changing its shape or size.
  • Deformation implies the change in shape and/or size of the body from an initial or undeformed configuration κ0(B)\kappa_0 (\mathcal{B})κ0​(B) to a current or deformed configuration κt(B)\kappa_t (\mathcal{B})κt​(B) (Figure 1).
A change in the configuration of a continuum body can be described by a displacement field. A displacement field is a vector field of all displacement vectors for all particles in the body, which relates the deformed configuration with the undeformed configuration. The distance between any two particles changes if and only if deformation has occurred. If displacement occurs without deformation, then it is a rigid-body displacement.

Deformation Gradient Tensor

The deformation gradient tensor F(X,t)=FjKej⊗IK\mathbf{F} (\mathbf{X}, t) = F_{jK} \mathbf{e}_{j} \otimes \mathbf{I}_{K}F(X,t)=FjK​ej​⊗IK​ is related to both the reference and current configuration, as seen by the unit vectors ej\mathbf{e}_{j}ej​ and IK\mathbf{I}_{K}IK​, therefore it is a two-point tensor. Two types of deformation gradient tensor may be defined. Due to the assumption of continuity of χ(X,t)\chi (\mathbf{X}, t)χ(X,t), F\mathbf{F}F has the inverse H=F−1\mathbf{H} = \mathbf{F} ^{-1}H=F−1, where H\mathbf{H}H is the spatial deformation gradient tensor. Then, by the implicit function theorem, the Jacobian determinant J(X,t)J (\mathbf{X}, t)J(X,t) must be nonsingular, i.e. J(X,t)=det⁡F(X,t)≠0J (\mathbf{X}, t) = \det \mathbf{F} (\mathbf{X}, t) \neq 0J(X,t)=detF(X,t)=0 The material deformation gradient tensor F(X,t)=FjKej⊗IK\mathbf{F} (\mathbf{X} , t) = F_{jK} \mathbf{e}_{j} \otimes \mathbf{I}_{K}F(X,t)=FjK​ej​⊗IK​ is a second-order tensor that represents the gradient of the mapping function or functional relation χ(X,t)\chi (\mathbf{X} , t)χ(X,t), which describes the motion of a continuum. The material deformation gradient tensor characterizes the local deformation at a material point with position vector X\mathbf{X}X, i.e., deformation at neighbouring points, by transforming (linear transformation) a material line element emanating from that point from the reference configuration to the current or deformed configuration, assuming continuity in the mapping function χ(X,t)\chi (\mathbf{X} , t)χ(X,t), i.e. differentiable function of X\mathbf{X}X and time ttt, which implies that cracks and voids do not open or close during the deformation. Thus we have, dx=∂x∂X dXordxj=∂xj∂XK dXK=∇χ(X,t) dXordxj=FjK dXK .=F(X,t) dX\begin{aligned} d \mathbf{x} &= \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \, d \mathbf{X} & \qquad \text{or} \qquad & dx_{j} = \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \, dX_{K} \\ &= \nabla \chi (\mathbf{X} , t) \, d \mathbf{X} & \qquad \text{or} \qquad & dx_{j} = F_{jK} \, dX_{K} \,. \\ &= \mathbf{F} (\mathbf{X} , t) \, d \mathbf{X} \end{aligned}dx​=∂X∂x​dX=∇χ(X,t)dX=F(X,t)dX​oror​dxj​=∂XK​∂xj​​dXK​dxj​=FjK​dXK​.​

Relative Displacement Vector

Consider a particle or material point PPP with position vector X=XIII\mathbf{X} = X_{I} \mathbf{I}_{I}X=XI​II​ in the undeformed configuration (Figure 2). After a displacement of the body, the new position of the particle indicated by ppp in the new configuration is given by the vector position x=xiei\mathbf{x} = x_{i} \mathbf{e}_{i}x=xi​ei​. The coordinate systems for the undeformed and deformed configuration can be superimposed for convenience. Consider now a material point QQQ neighboring PPP, with position vector X+ΔX=(XI+ΔXI)II\mathbf{X} + \Delta \mathbf{X} = (X_{I} + \Delta X_{I}) \mathbf{I}_{I}X+ΔX=(XI​+ΔXI​)II​. In the deformed configuration this particle has a new position qqq given by the position vector x+Δx\mathbf{x} + \Delta \mathbf{x}x+Δx. Assuming that the line segments ΔX\Delta XΔX and Δx\Delta \mathbf{x}Δx joining the particles PPP and QQQ in both the undeformed and deformed configuration, respectively, to be very small, then we can express them as dXd \mathbf{X}dX and dxd \mathbf{x}dx. Thus from Figure 2 we have x=X+u(X),x+dx=X+dX+u(X+dX),and therefore dx=X−x+dX+u(X+dX)=dX+u(X+dX)−u(X)=dX+du,\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x} &= \mathbf{X} + \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} ), \\ \mathbf{x} + d \mathbf{x} &= \mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{X} + \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{X} ), \\ \text{and therefore} &\ \\ d \mathbf{x} &= \mathbf{X} - \mathbf{x} + d \mathbf{X} + \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{X} ) \\ &= d \mathbf{X} + \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{X} ) - \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} ) \\ &= d \mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{u} \end{aligned},xx+dxand thereforedx​=X+u(X),=X+dX+u(X+dX), =X−x+dX+u(X+dX)=dX+u(X+dX)−u(X)=dX+du​, where dud \mathbf{u}du is the relative displacement vector, which represents the relative displacement of QQQ with respect to PPP in the deformed configuration.

Taylor Approximation

For an infinitesimal element dXd \mathbf{X}dX, and assuming continuity on the displacement field, it is possible to use a Taylor series expansion around point PPP, neglecting higher-order terms, to approximate the components of the relative displacement vector for the neighboring particle QQQ as u(X+dX)=u(X)+duorui∗=ui+dui≈u(X)+∇Xu⋅dXorui∗≈ui+∂ui∂XJdXJ .\begin{aligned} \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{X} ) &= \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} ) + d \mathbf{u} \quad & \text{or} \quad & u_{i}^{*} = u_{i} + du_{i} \\ &\approx \mathbf{u} (\mathbf{X} ) + \nabla_{\mathbf{X} } \mathbf{u} \cdot d \mathbf{X} \quad & \text{or} \quad & u_{i}^{*} \approx u_{i} + \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial X_{J}} dX_{J} \,. \end{aligned}u(X+dX)​=u(X)+du≈u(X)+∇X​u⋅dX​oror​ui∗​=ui​+dui​ui∗​≈ui​+∂XJ​∂ui​​dXJ​.​ Thus, the previous equation dx=dX+dud \mathbf{x} = d \mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{u}dx=dX+du can be written as dx=dX+du=dX+∇Xu⋅dX=(I+∇Xu)dX=FdX\begin{aligned} d \mathbf{x} &= d \mathbf{X} + d \mathbf{u} \\ &= d \mathbf{X} + \nabla_{\mathbf{X} } \mathbf{u} \cdot d \mathbf{X} \\ &= \left( \mathbf{I} + \nabla_{\mathbf{X} } \mathbf{u} \right) d \mathbf{X} \\ &= \mathbf{F} d \mathbf{X} \end{aligned}dx​=dX+du=dX+∇X​u⋅dX=(I+∇X​u)dX=FdX​

Time-Derivative of the Deformation Gradient

Calculations that involve the time-dependent deformation of a body often require a time derivative of the deformation gradient to be calculated. A geometrically consistent definition of such a derivative requires an excursion into differential geometry but we avoid those issues in this article. The time derivative of F\mathbf{F}F is F˙=∂F∂t=∂∂t[∂x(X,t)∂X]=∂∂X[∂x(X,t)∂t]=∂∂X[V(X,t)]\dot{\mathbf{F}} = \frac{\partial \mathbf{F}}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left[ \frac{\partial \mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t)}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \right] = \frac{\partial}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \left[ \frac{\partial \mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t)}{\partial t} \right] = \frac{\partial}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \left[ \mathbf{V} (\mathbf{X} , t) \right]F˙=∂t∂F​=∂t∂​[∂X∂x(X,t)​]=∂X∂​[∂t∂x(X,t)​]=∂X∂​[V(X,t)] where V\mathbf{V}V is the (material) velocity. The derivative on the right hand side represents a material velocity gradient. It is common to convert that into a spatial gradient by applying the chain rule for derivatives, i.e., F˙=∂∂X[V(X,t)]=∂∂X[v(x(X,t),t)]=∂∂x[v(x,t)]∣x=x(X,t)⋅∂x(X,t)∂X=l⋅F\dot{\mathbf{F}} = \frac{\partial}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \left[ \mathbf{V} (\mathbf{X} , t) \right] = \frac{\partial}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \left[ \mathbf{v} (\mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t), t) \right] = \left. \frac{\partial}{\partial \mathbf{x}} \left[ \mathbf{v} (\mathbf{x} , t) \right] \right|_{\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t)} \cdot \frac{\partial \mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t)}{\partial \mathbf{X}} = \boldsymbol{l} \cdot \mathbf{F}F˙=∂X∂​[V(X,t)]=∂X∂​[v(x(X,t),t)]=∂x∂​[v(x,t)]​x=x(X,t)​⋅∂X∂x(X,t)​=l⋅F where l=(∇xv)T\boldsymbol{l} = (\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} \mathbf{v})^{T}l=(∇x​v)T is the spatial velocity gradient and where v(x,t)=V(X,t)\mathbf{v} (\mathbf{x} , t) = \mathbf{V} (\mathbf{X} , t)v(x,t)=V(X,t) is the spatial (Eulerian) velocity at x=x(X,t)\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{x} (\mathbf{X} , t)x=x(X,t). If the spatial velocity gradient is constant in time, the above equation can be solved exactly to give F=el t\mathbf{F} = e^{\boldsymbol{l}\, t}F=elt assuming F=1\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{1}F=1 at t=0t = 0t=0. There are several methods of computing the exponential above. Related quantities often used in continuum mechanics are the rate of deformation tensor and the spin tensor defined, respectively, as: d=12(l+lT) ,w=12(l−lT) .\boldsymbol{d} = \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{l} + \boldsymbol{l}^{T} \right) \,, \quad \boldsymbol{w} = \tfrac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{l} - \boldsymbol{l}^{T} \right) \,. d=21​(l+lT),w=21​(l−lT). The rate of deformation tensor gives the rate of stretching of line elements while the spin tensor indicates the rate of rotation or vorticity of the motion. The material time derivative of the inverse of the deformation gradient (keeping the reference configuration fixed) is often required in analyses that involve finite strains. This derivative is ∂∂t(F−1)=−F−1⋅F˙⋅F−1 .\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left( \mathbf{F}^{-1} \right) = - \mathbf{F}^{-1} \cdot \dot{\mathbf{F}} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{-1} \,. ∂t∂​(F−1)=−F−1⋅F˙⋅F−1. The above relation can be verified by taking the material time derivative of F−1⋅dx=dX\mathbf{F}^{-1} \cdot d \mathbf{x} = d \mathbf{X}F−1⋅dx=dX and noting that X˙=0\dot{\mathbf{X}} = 0X˙=0.

Polar Decomposition of the Deformation Gradient Tensor

The deformation gradient F\mathbf{F}F, like any invertible second-order tensor, can be decomposed, using the polar decomposition theorem, into a product of two second-order tensors (Truesdell and Noll, 1965): an orthogonal tensor and a positive definite symmetric tensor, i.e., F=RU=VR\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{R} \mathbf{U} = \mathbf{V} \mathbf{R}F=RU=VR where the tensor R\mathbf{R}R is a proper orthogonal tensor, i.e., R−1=RT\mathbf{R}^{-1} = \mathbf{R}^{T}R−1=RT and det⁡R=+1\det \mathbf{R} = +1detR=+1, representing a rotation; the tensor U\mathbf{U}U is the right stretch tensor; and V\mathbf{V}V the left stretch tensor. The terms right and left means that they are to the right and left of the rotation tensor R\mathbf{R}R, respectively. U\mathbf{U}U and V\mathbf{V}V are both positive definite, i.e. x⋅U⋅x>0\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{U} \cdot \mathbf{x} > 0x⋅U⋅x>0 and x⋅V⋅x>0\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{V} \cdot \mathbf{x} > 0x⋅V⋅x>0 for all non-zero x∈R3\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{3}x∈R3, and symmetric tensors, i.e. U=UT\mathbf{U} = \mathbf{U}^{T}U=UT and V=VT\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{V}^{T}V=VT, of second order. This decomposition implies that the deformation of a line element dXd \mathbf{X}dX in the undeformed configuration onto dxd \mathbf{x}dx in the deformed configuration, i.e., dx=F dXd \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{F} \, d \mathbf{X}dx=FdX, may be obtained either by first stretching the element by U\mathbf{U}U, i.e. dx′=U dXd \mathbf{x}' = \mathbf{U} \, d \mathbf{X}dx′=UdX, followed by a rotation R\mathbf{R}R, i.e., dx=R dx′d \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{R} \, d \mathbf{x}'dx=Rdx′; or equivalently, by applying a rigid rotation R\mathbf{R}R first, i.e., dx′=R dXd \mathbf{x}' = \mathbf{R} \, d \mathbf{X}dx′=RdX, followed later by a stretching V\mathbf{V}V, i.e., dx=V dx′d \mathbf{x} = \mathbf{V} \, d \mathbf{x}'dx=Vdx′ (See Figure 3). Due to the orthogonality of R\mathbf{R}R V=R⋅U⋅RT\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{R} \cdot \mathbf{U} \cdot \mathbf{R}^{T}V=R⋅U⋅RT so that U\mathbf{U}U and V\mathbf{V}V have the same eigenvalues or principal stretches, but different eigenvectors or principal directions Ni\mathbf{N}_{i}Ni​ and ni\mathbf{n}_{i}ni​, respectively. The principal directions are related by ni=RNi\mathbf{n}_{i} = \mathbf{R} \mathbf{N}_{i}ni​=RNi​. This polar decomposition, which is unique as F\mathbf{F}F is invertible with a positive determinant, is a corollary of the singular-value decomposition.

Transformation of a Surface and Volume Element

To transform quantities that are defined with respect to areas in a deformed configuration to those relative to areas in a reference configuration, and vice versa, we use Nanson's relation, expressed as da n=J dA F−T⋅Nda \, \mathbf{n} = J \, dA \, \mathbf{F}^{-T} \cdot \mathbf{N}dan=JdAF−T⋅N where dadada is an area of a region in the deformed configuration, dAdAdA is the same area in the reference configuration, and n\mathbf{n}n is the outward normal to the area element in the current configuration while N\mathbf{N}N is the outward normal in the reference configuration, F\mathbf{F}F is the deformation gradient, and J=det⁡FJ = \det \mathbf{F}J=detF. The corresponding formula for the transformation of the volume element is dv=J dVdv = J \, dVdv=JdV Derivation of Nanson's relation (see also) To see how this formula is derived, we start with the oriented area elements in the reference and current configurations: dA=dA N ;  da=da nd \mathbf{A} = dA \, \mathbf{N} ~; ~~ d \mathbf{a} = da \, \mathbf{n}dA=dAN ;  da=dan The reference and current volumes of an element are dV=dAT⋅dL ;  dv=daT⋅dldV = d \mathbf{A}^{T} \cdot d \mathbf{L} ~; ~~ dv = d \mathbf{a}^{T} \cdot d \mathbf{l}dV=dAT⋅dL ;  dv=daT⋅dl where dl=F⋅dLd \mathbf{l} = \mathbf{F} \cdot d \mathbf{L}dl=F⋅dL. Therefore, daT⋅dl=dv=J dV=J dAT⋅dLd \mathbf{a}^{T} \cdot d \mathbf{l} = dv = J ~ dV = J ~ d \mathbf{A}^{T} \cdot d \mathbf{L}daT⋅dl=dv=J dV=J dAT⋅dL or, daT⋅F⋅dL=dv=J dV=J dAT⋅dLd \mathbf{a}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d \mathbf{L} = dv = J ~ dV = J ~ d \mathbf{A}^{T} \cdot d \mathbf{L}daT⋅F⋅dL=dv=J dV=J dAT⋅dL so, daT⋅F=J dATd \mathbf{a}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} = J ~ d \mathbf{A}^{T}daT⋅F=J dAT So we get da=J F−T⋅dAd \mathbf{a} = J ~ \mathbf{F}^{-T} \cdot d \mathbf{A}da=J F−T⋅dA or, da n=J dA F−T⋅Nda \, \mathbf{n} = J ~ dA ~ \mathbf{F}^{-T} \cdot \mathbf{N}dan=J dA F−T⋅N [Q.E.D.]

Fundamental strain tensors

A strain tensor is defined by the IUPAC as:
"A symmetric tensor that results when a deformation gradient tensor is factorized into a rotation tensor followed or preceded by a symmetric tensor".
Since a pure rotation should not induce any strains in a deformable body, it is often convenient to use rotation-independent measures of deformation in continuum mechanics. As a rotation followed by its inverse rotation leads to no change ( RRT=RTR=I\mathbf{R} \mathbf{R}^T = \mathbf{R}^T \mathbf{R} = \mathbf{I}RRT=RTR=I ) we can exclude the rotation by multiplying the deformation gradient tensor F\mathbf{F}F by its transpose. Several rotation-independent deformation gradient tensors (or "deformation tensors", for short) are used in mechanics. In solid mechanics, the most popular of these are the right and left Cauchy–Green deformation tensors.

Cauchy strain tensor (right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor)

In 1839, George Green introduced a deformation tensor known as the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor or Green's deformation tensor (the IUPAC recommends that this tensor be called the Cauchy strain tensor), defined as: C=FTF=U2orCIJ=FkIFkJ=∂xk∂XI∂xk∂XJ.\mathbf{C} = \mathbf{F}^T \mathbf{F} = \mathbf{U}^2 \quad \text{or} \quad C_{IJ} = F_{kI} F_{kJ} = \frac{\partial x_k}{\partial X_I} \frac{\partial x_k}{\partial X_J}.C=FTF=U2orCIJ​=FkI​FkJ​=∂XI​∂xk​​∂XJ​∂xk​​. Physically, the Cauchy–Green tensor gives us the square of local change in distances due to deformation, i.e. dx2=dX⋅C⋅dXd\mathbf{x}^2 = d\mathbf{X} \cdot \mathbf{C} \cdot d\mathbf{X}dx2=dX⋅C⋅dX Invariants of C\mathbf{C}C are often used in the expressions for strain energy density functions. The most commonly used invariants are I1C:=tr(C)=CII=λ12+λ22+λ32I_1^C := \mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{C}) = C_{II} = \lambda_1^2 + \lambda_2^2 + \lambda_3^2I1C​:=tr(C)=CII​=λ12​+λ22​+λ32​ I2C:=12[(trC)2−tr(C2)]=12[(CJJ)2−CIKCKI]=λ12λ22+λ22λ32+λ32λ12I_2^C := \tfrac{1}{2} \left[ (\mathrm{tr} \mathbf{C})^2 - \mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{C}^2) \right] = \tfrac{1}{2} \left[ (C_{JJ})^2 - C_{IK} C_{KI} \right] = \lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2 + \lambda_2^2 \lambda_3^2 + \lambda_3^2 \lambda_1^2I2C​:=21​[(trC)2−tr(C2)]=21​[(CJJ​)2−CIK​CKI​]=λ12​λ22​+λ22​λ32​+λ32​λ12​ I3C:=det⁡(C)=J2=λ12λ22λ32.I_3^C := \det(\mathbf{C}) = J^2 = \lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2 \lambda_3^2 .I3C​:=det(C)=J2=λ12​λ22​λ32​. where J:=det⁡FJ := \det \mathbf{F}J:=detF is the determinant of the deformation gradient F\mathbf{F}F and λi\lambda_iλi​ are stretch ratios for the unit fibers that are initially oriented along the eigenvector directions of the right (reference) stretch tensor (these are not generally aligned with the three axis of the coordinate systems).

Finger strain tensor

The IUPAC recommends that the inverse of the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor (called the Cauchy strain tensor in that document), i. e., C−1\mathbf{C}^{-1}C−1, be called the Finger strain tensor. However, that nomenclature is not universally accepted in applied mechanics. f=C−1=F−1F−TorfIJ=∂XI∂xk∂XJ∂xk\mathbf{f} = \mathbf{C}^{-1} = \mathbf{F}^{-1} \mathbf{F}^{-T} \quad \text{or} \quad f_{IJ} = \frac{\partial X_I}{\partial x_k} \frac{\partial X_J}{\partial x_k}f=C−1=F−1F−TorfIJ​=∂xk​∂XI​​∂xk​∂XJ​​

Green strain tensor (left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor)

Reversing the order of multiplication in the formula for the right Cauchy-Green deformation tensor leads to the left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor which is defined as: B=FFT=V2orBij=∂xi∂XK∂xj∂XK\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{F} \mathbf{F}^T = \mathbf{V}^2 \quad \text{or} \quad B_{ij} = \frac{\partial x_i}{\partial X_K} \frac{\partial x_j}{\partial X_K}B=FFT=V2orBij​=∂XK​∂xi​​∂XK​∂xj​​ The left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor is often called the Finger deformation tensor , named after Josef Finger (1894). The IUPAC recommends that this tensor be called the Green strain tensor. Invariants of B\mathbf{B}B are also used in the expressions for strain energy density functions. The conventional invariants are defined as I1:=tr(B)=Bii=λ12+λ22+λ32I_1 := \mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{B}) = B_{ii} = \lambda_1^2 + \lambda_2^2 + \lambda_3^2I1​:=tr(B)=Bii​=λ12​+λ22​+λ32​ I2:=12[(trB)2−tr(B2)]=12(Bii2−BjkBkj)=λ12λ22+λ22λ32+λ32λ12I_2 := \tfrac{1}{2} \left[ (\mathrm{tr} \mathbf{B})^2 - \mathrm{tr}(\mathbf{B}^2) \right] = \tfrac{1}{2} (B_{ii}^2 - B_{jk} B_{kj}) = \lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2 + \lambda_2^2 \lambda_3^2 + \lambda_3^2 \lambda_1^2I2​:=21​[(trB)2−tr(B2)]=21​(Bii2​−Bjk​Bkj​)=λ12​λ22​+λ22​λ32​+λ32​λ12​ I3:=det⁡B=J2=λ12λ22λ32I_3 := \det \mathbf{B} = J^2 = \lambda_1^2 \lambda_2^2 \lambda_3^2I3​:=detB=J2=λ12​λ22​λ32​ where J:=det⁡FJ := \det \mathbf{F}J:=detF is the determinant of the deformation gradient. For compressible materials, a slightly different set of invariants is used: (Iˉ1:=J−2/3I1;Iˉ2:=J−4/3I2;J≠1).( \bar{I}_1 := J^{-2/3} I_1 ; \bar{I}_2 := J^{-4/3} I_2 ; J \neq 1 ) .(Iˉ1​:=J−2/3I1​;Iˉ2​:=J−4/3I2​;J=1).

Piola strain tensor (Cauchy deformation tensor)

Earlier in 1828, Augustin-Louis Cauchy introduced a deformation tensor defined as the inverse of the left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor, B−1\mathbf{B}^{-1}B−1. This tensor has also been called the Piola strain tensor by the IUPAC and the Finger tensor in the rheology and fluid dynamics literature. c=B−1=F−TF−1orcij=∂XK∂xi∂XK∂xj\mathbf{c} = \mathbf{B}^{-1} = \mathbf{F}^{-T} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \quad \text{or} \quad c_{ij} = \frac{\partial X_K}{\partial x_i} \frac{\partial X_K}{\partial x_j}c=B−1=F−TF−1orcij​=∂xi​∂XK​​∂xj​∂XK​​

Spectral representation

If there are three distinct principal stretches λi\lambda_iλi​, the spectral decompositions of C\mathbf{C}C and B\mathbf{B}B is given by C=∑i=13λi2Ni⊗NiandB=∑i=13λi2ni⊗ni\mathbf{C} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i^2 \mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i \quad \text{and} \quad \mathbf{B} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i^2 \mathbf{n}_i \otimes \mathbf{n}_iC=i=1∑3​λi2​Ni​⊗Ni​andB=i=1∑3​λi2​ni​⊗ni​ Furthermore, U=∑i=13λiNi⊗Ni;V=∑i=13λini⊗ni\mathbf{U} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i \mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i ; \mathbf{V} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i \mathbf{n}_i \otimes \mathbf{n}_iU=i=1∑3​λi​Ni​⊗Ni​;V=i=1∑3​λi​ni​⊗ni​ R=∑i=13ni⊗Ni;F=∑i=13λini⊗Ni\mathbf{R} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \mathbf{n}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i ; \mathbf{F} = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i \mathbf{n}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_iR=i=1∑3​ni​⊗Ni​;F=i=1∑3​λi​ni​⊗Ni​ Observe that V=RURT=∑i=13λiR(Ni⊗Ni)RT=∑i=13λi(RNi)⊗(RNi)\mathbf{V} = \mathbf{R} \mathbf{U} \mathbf{R}^T = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i \mathbf{R} (\mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i) \mathbf{R}^T = \sum_{i=1}^{3} \lambda_i (\mathbf{R} \mathbf{N}_i) \otimes (\mathbf{R} \mathbf{N}_i)V=RURT=∑i=13​λi​R(Ni​⊗Ni​)RT=∑i=13​λi​(RNi​)⊗(RNi​) Therefore, the uniqueness of the spectral decomposition also implies that ni=RNi\mathbf{n}_i = \mathbf{R} \mathbf{N}_ini​=RNi​. The left stretch ( V\mathbf{V}V ) is also called the spatial stretch tensor while the right stretch ( U\mathbf{U}U ) is called the material stretch tensor. The effect of F\mathbf{F}F acting on Ni\mathbf{N}_iNi​ is to stretch the vector by λi\lambda_iλi​ and to rotate it to the new orientation ni\mathbf{n}_ini​, i.e., FNi=λi(RNi)=λini\mathbf{F} \mathbf{N}_i = \lambda_i (\mathbf{R} \mathbf{N}_i) = \lambda_i \mathbf{n}_iFNi​=λi​(RNi​)=λi​ni​ In a similar vein, F−TNi=1λini;FTni=λiNi;F−1ni=1λiNi.\mathbf{F}^{-T} \mathbf{N}_i = \frac{1}{\lambda_i} \mathbf{n}_i ; \mathbf{F}^T \mathbf{n}_i = \lambda_i \mathbf{N}_i ; \mathbf{F}^{-1} \mathbf{n}_i = \frac{1}{\lambda_i} \mathbf{N}_i .F−TNi​=λi​1​ni​;FTni​=λi​Ni​;F−1ni​=λi​1​Ni​.

Examples

Uniaxial extension of an incompressible material
This is the case where a specimen is stretched in 1-direction with a stretch ratio of α=α1\alpha = \alpha_1α=α1​. If the volume remains constant, the contraction in the other two directions is such that α1α2α3=1\alpha_1 \alpha_2 \alpha_3 = 1α1​α2​α3​=1 or α2=α3=α−0.5\alpha_2 = \alpha_3 = \alpha^{-0.5}α2​=α3​=α−0.5. Then: F=[α000α−0.5000α−0.5]\mathbf{F} = \begin{bmatrix} \alpha & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \alpha^{-0.5} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \alpha^{-0.5} \end{bmatrix}F=​α00​0α−0.50​00α−0.5​​ B=C=[α2000α−1000α−1]\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{C} = \begin{bmatrix} \alpha^2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \alpha^{-1} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & \alpha^{-1} \end{bmatrix}B=C=​α200​0α−10​00α−1​​ Simple shear F=[1γ0010001]\mathbf{F} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & \gamma & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}F=​100​γ10​001​​ B=[1+γ2γ0γ10001]\mathbf{B} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 + \gamma^2 & \gamma & 0 \\ \gamma & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}B=​1+γ2γ0​γ10​001​​ C=[1γ0γ1+γ20001]\mathbf{C} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & \gamma & 0 \\ \gamma & 1 + \gamma^2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}C=​1γ0​γ1+γ20​001​​ Rigid body rotation F=[cos⁡θsin⁡θ0−sin⁡θcos⁡θ0001]\mathbf{F} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \theta & \sin \theta & 0 \\ -\sin \theta & \cos \theta & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}F=​cosθ−sinθ0​sinθcosθ0​001​​ B=C=[100010001]=1\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{C} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \mathbf{1}B=C=​100​010​001​​=1

Derivatives of stretch

Derivatives of the stretch with respect to the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor are used to derive the stress-strain relations of many solids, particularly hyperelastic materials. These derivatives are ∂λi∂C=12λiNi⊗Ni=12λiRT(ni⊗ni)R;i=1,2,3\frac{\partial \lambda_i}{\partial \mathbf{C}} = \frac{1}{2 \lambda_i} \mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i = \frac{1}{2 \lambda_i} \mathbf{R}^T (\mathbf{n}_i \otimes \mathbf{n}_i) \mathbf{R} ; i=1,2,3∂C∂λi​​=2λi​1​Ni​⊗Ni​=2λi​1​RT(ni​⊗ni​)R;i=1,2,3 and follow from the observations that C:(Ni⊗Ni)=λi2;∂C∂C=I(s);I(s):(Ni⊗Ni)=Ni⊗Ni.\mathbf{C} : (\mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i) = \lambda_i^2 ; \frac{\partial \mathbf{C}}{\partial \mathbf{C}} = \mathsf{I}^{(s)} ; \mathsf{I}^{(s)} : (\mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i) = \mathbf{N}_i \otimes \mathbf{N}_i .C:(Ni​⊗Ni​)=λi2​;∂C∂C​=I(s);I(s):(Ni​⊗Ni​)=Ni​⊗Ni​.

Physical interpretation of deformation tensors

Let X=XiEi\mathbf{X} = X^i \boldsymbol{E}_iX=XiEi​ be a Cartesian coordinate system defined on the undeformed body and let x=xiEi\mathbf{x} = x^i \boldsymbol{E}_ix=xiEi​ be another system defined on the deformed body. Let a curve X(s)\mathbf{X}(s)X(s) in the undeformed body be parametrized using s∈[0,1]s \in [0,1]s∈[0,1]. Its image in the deformed body is x(X(s))\mathbf{x}(\mathbf{X}(s))x(X(s)). The undeformed length of the curve is given by lX=∫01∣dXds∣ds=∫01dXds⋅dXdsds=∫01dXds⋅I⋅dXdsdsl_X = \int_0^1 \left| \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \right| ds = \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} } ds = \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \cdot \boldsymbol{I} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} } dslX​=∫01​​dsdX​​ds=∫01​dsdX​⋅dsdX​​ds=∫01​dsdX​⋅I⋅dsdX​​ds After deformation, the length becomes lx=∫01∣dxds∣ds=∫01dxds⋅dxdsds=∫01(dxdX⋅dXds)⋅(dxdX⋅dXds)ds=∫01dXds⋅[(dxdX)T⋅dxdX]⋅dXdsds\begin{aligned} l_x &= \int_0^1 \left| \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{ds} \right| ds = \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{ds} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{ds} } ds = \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \left( \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \right) \cdot \left( \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \right) } ds \\ &= \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \cdot \left[ \left( \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}} \right)^T \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}} \right] \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} } ds \end{aligned}lx​​=∫01​​dsdx​​ds=∫01​dsdx​⋅dsdx​​ds=∫01​(dXdx​⋅dsdX​)⋅(dXdx​⋅dsdX​)​ds=∫01​dsdX​⋅[(dXdx​)T⋅dXdx​]⋅dsdX​​ds​ Note that the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor is defined as C:=FT⋅F=(dxdX)T⋅dxdX\boldsymbol{C} := \boldsymbol{F}^T \cdot \boldsymbol{F} = \left( \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}} \right)^T \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{x}}{d \mathbf{X}}C:=FT⋅F=(dXdx​)T⋅dXdx​ Hence, lx=∫01dXds⋅C⋅dXdsdsl_x = \int_0^1 \sqrt{ \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} \cdot \boldsymbol{C} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{X}}{ds} } dslx​=∫01​dsdX​⋅C⋅dsdX​​ds which indicates that changes in length are characterized by C\boldsymbol{C}C.

Finite strain tensors

The concept of strain is used to evaluate how much a given displacement differs locally from a rigid body displacement. One of such strains for large deformations is the Lagrangian finite strain tensor , also called the Green-Lagrangian strain tensor or Green–St-Venant strain tensor , defined as E=12(C−I)orEKL=12(∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL−δKL)\mathbf{E} = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{C} - \mathbf{I} ) \qquad \text{or} \qquad E_{KL} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} - \delta_{KL} \right)E=21​(C−I)orEKL​=21​(∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​−δKL​) or as a function of the displacement gradient tensor E=12[(∇Xu)T+∇Xu+(∇Xu)T⋅∇Xu]\mathbf{E} = \frac{1}{2} \left[ ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} )^{T} + \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} + ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} )^{T} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} \right]E=21​[(∇X​u)T+∇X​u+(∇X​u)T⋅∇X​u] or EKL=12(∂uK∂XL+∂uL∂XK+∂uM∂XK∂uM∂XL)E_{KL} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial u_{K}}{\partial X_{L}} + \frac{\partial u_{L}}{\partial X_{K}} + \frac{\partial u_{M}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial u_{M}}{\partial X_{L}} \right)EKL​=21​(∂XL​∂uK​​+∂XK​∂uL​​+∂XK​∂uM​​∂XL​∂uM​​) The Green-Lagrangian strain tensor is a measure of how much C\mathbf{C}C differs from I\mathbf{I}I. The Eulerian finite strain tensor , or Eulerian-Almansi finite strain tensor , referenced to the deformed configuration (i.e. Eulerian description) is defined as e=12(I−c)=12(I−B−1)orers=12(δrs−∂XM∂xr∂XM∂xs)\mathbf{e} = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{c} ) = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{B}^{-1} ) \qquad \text{or} \qquad e_{rs} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \delta_{rs} - \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{r}} \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{s}} \right)e=21​(I−c)=21​(I−B−1)orers​=21​(δrs​−∂xr​∂XM​​∂xs​∂XM​​) or as a function of the displacement gradients we have eij=12(∂ui∂xj+∂uj∂xi−∂uk∂xi∂uk∂xj)e_{ij} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} + \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}} - \frac{\partial u_{k}}{\partial x_{i}} \frac{\partial u_{k}}{\partial x_{j}} \right)eij​=21​(∂xj​∂ui​​+∂xi​∂uj​​−∂xi​∂uk​​∂xj​∂uk​​)

Derivation of the Lagrangian and Eulerian finite strain tensors

A measure of deformation is the difference between the squares of the differential line element dXd\mathbf{X}dX, in the undeformed configuration, and dxd\mathbf{x}dx, in the deformed configuration (Figure 2). Deformation has occurred if the difference is non zero, otherwise a rigid-body displacement has occurred. Thus we have, dx2−dX2=dx⋅dx−dX⋅dXor(dx)2−(dX)2=dxjdxj−dXM dXMd\mathbf{x}^{2} - d\mathbf{X}^{2} = d\mathbf{x} \cdot d\mathbf{x} - d\mathbf{X} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \qquad \text{or} \qquad (dx)^{2} - (dX)^{2} = dx_{j} dx_{j} - dX_{M} \, dX_{M}dx2−dX2=dx⋅dx−dX⋅dXor(dx)2−(dX)2=dxj​dxj​−dXM​dXM​ In the Lagrangian description, using the material coordinates as the frame of reference, the linear transformation between the differential lines is dx=∂x∂X dX=F dXordxj=∂xj∂XM dXMd\mathbf{x} = \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \mathbf{X}} \, d\mathbf{X} = \mathbf{F} \, d\mathbf{X} \qquad \text{or} \qquad dx_{j} = \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{M}} \, dX_{M}dx=∂X∂x​dX=FdXordxj​=∂XM​∂xj​​dXM​ Then we have, dx2=dx⋅dx=F⋅dX⋅F⋅dX=dX⋅FTF⋅dX=dX⋅C⋅dXor(dx)2=dxj dxj=∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL dXK dXL=CKL dXK dXL\begin{aligned} d\mathbf{x}^{2} &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \\ &= \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \\ &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \\ &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot \mathbf{C} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \end{aligned} \qquad \text{or} \qquad \begin{aligned} (dx)^{2} &= dx_{j} \, dx_{j} \\ &= \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} \, dX_{K} \, dX_{L} \\ &= C_{KL} \, dX_{K} \, dX_{L} \end{aligned}dx2​=dx⋅dx=F⋅dX⋅F⋅dX=dX⋅FTF⋅dX=dX⋅C⋅dX​or(dx)2​=dxj​dxj​=∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​dXK​dXL​=CKL​dXK​dXL​​ where CKLC_{KL}CKL​ are the components of the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor , C=FTF\mathbf{C} = \mathbf{F}^{T} \mathbf{F}C=FTF. Then, replacing this equation into the first equation we have, dx2−dX2=dX⋅C⋅dX−dX⋅dX=dX⋅(C−I)⋅dX=dX⋅2E⋅dX\begin{aligned} d\mathbf{x}^{2} - d\mathbf{X}^{2} &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot \mathbf{C} \cdot d\mathbf{X} - d\mathbf{X} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \\ &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot ( \mathbf{C} - \mathbf{I} ) \cdot d\mathbf{X} \\ &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot 2 \mathbf{E} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \end{aligned}dx2−dX2​=dX⋅C⋅dX−dX⋅dX=dX⋅(C−I)⋅dX=dX⋅2E⋅dX​ or (dx)2−(dX)2=∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL dXK dXL−dXM dXM=(∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL−δKL) dXK dXL=2EKL dXK dXL\begin{aligned} (dx)^{2} - (dX)^{2} &= \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} \, dX_{K} \, dX_{L} - dX_{M} \, dX_{M} \\ &= \left( \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} - \delta_{KL} \right) \, dX_{K} \, dX_{L} \\ &= 2 E_{KL} \, dX_{K} \, dX_{L} \end{aligned}(dx)2−(dX)2​=∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​dXK​dXL​−dXM​dXM​=(∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​−δKL​)dXK​dXL​=2EKL​dXK​dXL​​ where EKLE_{KL}EKL​, are the components of a second-order tensor called the Green – St-Venant strain tensor or the Lagrangian finite strain tensor , E=12(C−I)orEKL=12(∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL−δKL)\mathbf{E} = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{C} - \mathbf{I} ) \qquad \text{or} \qquad E_{KL} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} - \delta_{KL} \right)E=21​(C−I)orEKL​=21​(∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​−δKL​) In the Eulerian description, using the spatial coordinates as the frame of reference, the linear transformation between the differential lines is dX=∂X∂xdx=F−1 dx=H dxordXM=∂XM∂xn dxnd\mathbf{X} = \frac{\partial \mathbf{X}}{\partial \mathbf{x}} d\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{F}^{-1} \, d\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{H} \, d\mathbf{x} \qquad \text{or} \qquad dX_{M} = \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{n}} \, dx_{n}dX=∂x∂X​dx=F−1dx=HdxordXM​=∂xn​∂XM​​dxn​ where ∂XM∂xn\frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{n}}∂xn​∂XM​​ are the components of the spatial deformation gradient tensor , H\mathbf{H}H. Thus we have dX2=dX⋅dX=F−1⋅dx⋅F−1⋅dx=dx⋅F−TF−1⋅dx=dx⋅c⋅dxor(dX)2=dXM dXM=∂XM∂xr∂XM∂xs dxr dxs=crs dxr dxs\begin{aligned} d\mathbf{X}^{2} &= d\mathbf{X} \cdot d\mathbf{X} \\ &= \mathbf{F}^{-1} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{-1} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \\ &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{-T} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \\ &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{c} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \end{aligned} \qquad \text{or} \qquad \begin{aligned} (dX)^{2} &= dX_{M} \, dX_{M} \\ &= \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{r}} \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{s}} \, dx_{r} \, dx_{s} \\ &= c_{rs} \, dx_{r} \, dx_{s} \end{aligned}dX2​=dX⋅dX=F−1⋅dx⋅F−1⋅dx=dx⋅F−TF−1⋅dx=dx⋅c⋅dx​or(dX)2​=dXM​dXM​=∂xr​∂XM​​∂xs​∂XM​​dxr​dxs​=crs​dxr​dxs​​ where the second order tensor crsc_{rs}crs​ is called Cauchy's deformation tensor , c=F−TF−1\mathbf{c} = \mathbf{F}^{-T} \mathbf{F}^{-1}c=F−TF−1. Then we have, dx2−dX2=dx⋅dx−dx⋅c⋅dx=dx⋅(I−c)⋅dx=dx⋅2e⋅dx\begin{aligned} d\mathbf{x}^{2} - d\mathbf{X}^{2} &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot d\mathbf{x} - d\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{c} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \\ &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot ( \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{c} ) \cdot d\mathbf{x} \\ &= d\mathbf{x} \cdot 2 \mathbf{e} \cdot d\mathbf{x} \end{aligned}dx2−dX2​=dx⋅dx−dx⋅c⋅dx=dx⋅(I−c)⋅dx=dx⋅2e⋅dx​ or (dx)2−(dX)2=dxj dxj−∂XM∂xr∂XM∂xs dxr dxs=(δrs−∂XM∂xr∂XM∂xs) dxr dxs=2ers dxr dxs\begin{aligned} (dx)^{2} - (dX)^{2} &= dx_{j} \, dx_{j} - \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{r}} \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{s}} \, dx_{r} \, dx_{s} \\ &= \left( \delta_{rs} - \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{r}} \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{s}} \right) \, dx_{r} \, dx_{s} \\ &= 2 e_{rs} \, dx_{r} \, dx_{s} \end{aligned}(dx)2−(dX)2​=dxj​dxj​−∂xr​∂XM​​∂xs​∂XM​​dxr​dxs​=(δrs​−∂xr​∂XM​​∂xs​∂XM​​)dxr​dxs​=2ers​dxr​dxs​​ where erse_{rs}ers​, are the components of a second-order tensor called the Eulerian-Almansi finite strain tensor , e=12(I−c)orers=12(δrs−∂XM∂xr∂XM∂xs)\mathbf{e} = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{c} ) \qquad \text{or} \qquad e_{rs} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \delta_{rs} - \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{r}} \frac{\partial X_{M}}{\partial x_{s}} \right)e=21​(I−c)orers​=21​(δrs​−∂xr​∂XM​​∂xs​∂XM​​) Both the Lagrangian and Eulerian finite strain tensors can be conveniently expressed in terms of the displacement gradient tensor. For the Lagrangian strain tensor, first we differentiate the displacement vector u(X,t)\mathbf{u} ( \mathbf{X} , t )u(X,t) with respect to the material coordinates XMX_{M}XM​ to obtain the material displacement gradient tensor , ∇Xu\nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u}∇X​u u(X,t)=x(X,t)−X∇Xu=F−IF=∇Xu+Iorui=xi−δiJXJδiJUJ=xi−δiJXJxi=δiJ(UJ+XJ)∂xi∂XK=δiJ(∂UJ∂XK+δJK)=∂ui∂XK+δiK\begin{aligned} \mathbf{u} ( \mathbf{X} , t ) &= \mathbf{x} ( \mathbf{X} , t ) - \mathbf{X} \\ \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} &= \mathbf{F} - \mathbf{I} \\ \mathbf{F} &= \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{I} \end{aligned} \qquad \text{or} \qquad \begin{aligned} u_{i} &= x_{i} - \delta_{iJ} X_{J} \\ \delta_{iJ} U_{J} &= x_{i} - \delta_{iJ} X_{J} \\ x_{i} &= \delta_{iJ} ( U_{J} + X_{J} ) \\ \frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial X_{K}} &= \delta_{iJ} \left( \frac{\partial U_{J}}{\partial X_{K}} + \delta_{JK} \right) \\ &= \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial X_{K}} + \delta_{iK} \end{aligned}u(X,t)∇X​uF​=x(X,t)−X=F−I=∇X​u+I​orui​δiJ​UJ​xi​∂XK​∂xi​​​=xi​−δiJ​XJ​=xi​−δiJ​XJ​=δiJ​(UJ​+XJ​)=δiJ​(∂XK​∂UJ​​+δJK​)=∂XK​∂ui​​+δiK​​ Replacing this equation into the expression for the Lagrangian finite strain tensor we have E=12(FTF−I)=12[{(∇Xu)T+I}(∇Xu+I)−I]=12[(∇Xu)T+∇Xu+(∇Xu)T⋅∇Xu]\begin{aligned} \mathbf{E} &= \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{F}^{T} \mathbf{F} - \mathbf{I} ) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \left\{ ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} )^{T} + \mathbf{I} \right\} ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{I} ) - \mathbf{I} \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} )^{T} + \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} + ( \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} )^{T} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{X}} \mathbf{u} \right] \end{aligned}E​=21​(FTF−I)=21​[{(∇X​u)T+I}(∇X​u+I)−I]=21​[(∇X​u)T+∇X​u+(∇X​u)T⋅∇X​u]​ or EKL=12(∂xj∂XK∂xj∂XL−δKL)=12[δjM(∂UM∂XK+δMK)δjN(∂UN∂XL+δNL)−δKL]=12[δMN(∂UM∂XK+δMK)(∂UN∂XL+δNL)−δKL]=12[(∂UM∂XK+δMK)(∂UM∂XL+δML)−δKL]=12(∂UK∂XL+∂UL∂XK+∂UM∂XK∂UM∂XL)\begin{aligned} E_{KL} &= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial x_{j}}{\partial X_{L}} - \delta_{KL} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \delta_{jM} \left( \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{K}} + \delta_{MK} \right) \delta_{jN} \left( \frac{\partial U_{N}}{\partial X_{L}} + \delta_{NL} \right) - \delta_{KL} \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \delta_{MN} \left( \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{K}} + \delta_{MK} \right) \left( \frac{\partial U_{N}}{\partial X_{L}} + \delta_{NL} \right) - \delta_{KL} \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \left( \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{K}} + \delta_{MK} \right) \left( \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{L}} + \delta_{ML} \right) - \delta_{KL} \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial U_{K}}{\partial X_{L}} + \frac{\partial U_{L}}{\partial X_{K}} + \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{K}} \frac{\partial U_{M}}{\partial X_{L}} \right) \end{aligned}EKL​​=21​(∂XK​∂xj​​∂XL​∂xj​​−δKL​)=21​[δjM​(∂XK​∂UM​​+δMK​)δjN​(∂XL​∂UN​​+δNL​)−δKL​]=21​[δMN​(∂XK​∂UM​​+δMK​)(∂XL​∂UN​​+δNL​)−δKL​]=21​[(∂XK​∂UM​​+δMK​)(∂XL​∂UM​​+δML​)−δKL​]=21​(∂XL​∂UK​​+∂XK​∂UL​​+∂XK​∂UM​​∂XL​∂UM​​)​ Similarly, the Eulerian-Almansi finite strain tensor can be expressed as eij=12(∂ui∂xj+∂uj∂xi−∂uk∂xi∂uk∂xj)e_{ij} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{\partial u_{i}}{\partial x_{j}} + \frac{\partial u_{j}}{\partial x_{i}} - \frac{\partial u_{k}}{\partial x_{i}} \frac{\partial u_{k}}{\partial x_{j}} \right)eij​=21​(∂xj​∂ui​​+∂xi​∂uj​​−∂xi​∂uk​​∂xj​∂uk​​)

Seth–Hill family of generalized strain tensors

B. R. Seth from the Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur was the first to show that the Green and Almansi strain tensors are special cases of a more general strain measure. The idea was further expanded upon by Rodney Hill in 1968. The Seth–Hill family of strain measures (also called Doyle-Ericksen tensors) can be expressed as E(m)=12m(U2m−I)=12m[Cm−I]\mathbf{E}_{(m)} = \frac{1}{2m} ( \mathbf{U}^{2m} - \mathbf{I} ) = \frac{1}{2m} \left[ \mathbf{C}^{m} - \mathbf{I} \right]E(m)​=2m1​(U2m−I)=2m1​[Cm−I] For different values of mmm we have:
  • Green-Lagrangian strain tensor E(1)=12(U2−I)=12(C−I)\mathbf{E}_{(1)} = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{U}^{2} - \mathbf{I} ) = \frac{1}{2} ( \mathbf{C} - \mathbf{I} )E(1)​=21​(U2−I)=21​(C−I)
  • Biot strain tensor E(1/2)=(U−I)=C1/2−I\mathbf{E}_{(1/2)} = ( \mathbf{U} - \mathbf{I} ) = \mathbf{C}^{1/2} - \mathbf{I}E(1/2)​=(U−I)=C1/2−I
  • Logarithmic strain, Natural strain, True strain, or Hencky strain E(0)=ln⁡U=12 ln⁡C\mathbf{E}_{(0)} = \ln \mathbf{U} = \frac{1}{2} \, \ln \mathbf{C}E(0)​=lnU=21​lnC
  • Almansi strain E(−1)=12[I−U−2]\mathbf{E}_{(-1)} = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \mathbf{I} - \mathbf{U}^{-2} \right]E(−1)​=21​[I−U−2]
The second-order approximation of these tensors is E(m)=ε+12(∇u)T⋅∇u−(1−m)εT⋅ε\mathbf{E}_{(m)} = \boldsymbol{\varepsilon} + \frac{1}{2} ( \nabla \mathbf{u} )^{T} \cdot \nabla \mathbf{u} - (1 - m) \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}^{T} \cdot \boldsymbol{\varepsilon}E(m)​=ε+21​(∇u)T⋅∇u−(1−m)εT⋅ε where ε\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}ε is the infinitesimal strain tensor. Many other different definitions of tensors E\mathbf{E}E are admissible, provided that they all satisfy the conditions that:
  • E\mathbf{E}E vanishes for all rigid-body motions
  • the dependence of E\mathbf{E}E on the displacement gradient tensor ∇u\nabla \mathbf{u}∇u is continuous, continuously differentiable and monotonic
  • it is also desired that E\mathbf{E}E reduces to the infinitesimal strain tensor ε\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}ε as the norm ∣∇u∣→0| \nabla \mathbf{u} | \to 0∣∇u∣→0
An example is the set of tensors E(n)=(Un−U−n)/2n\mathbf{E}^{(n)} = \left( \mathbf{U}^{n} - \mathbf{U}^{-n} \right) / 2nE(n)=(Un−U−n)/2n which do not belong to the Seth–Hill class, but have the same 2nd-order approximation as the Seth–Hill measures at m=0m = 0m=0 for any value of nnn.

Physical interpretation of the finite strain tensor

The diagonal components EKLE_{KL}EKL​ of the Lagrangian finite strain tensor are related to the normal strain, e.g. E11=e(I1)+12e(I1)2E_{11} = e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )} + \frac{1}{2} e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )}^{2}E11​=e(I1​)​+21​e(I1​)2​ where e(I1)e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )}e(I1​)​ is the normal strain or engineering strain in the direction I1\mathbf{I}_{1}I1​. The off-diagonal components EKLE_{KL}EKL​ of the Lagrangian finite strain tensor are related to shear strain, e.g. E12=122E11+12E22+1sin⁡ϕ12E_{12} = \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 E_{11} + 1} \sqrt{2 E_{22} + 1} \sin \phi_{12}E12​=21​2E11​+1​2E22​+1​sinϕ12​ where ϕ12\phi_{12}ϕ12​ is the change in the angle between two line elements that were originally perpendicular with directions I1\mathbf{I}_{1}I1​ and I2\mathbf{I}_{2}I2​, respectively. Under certain circumstances, i.e. small displacements and small displacement rates, the components of the Lagrangian finite strain tensor may be approximated by the components of the infinitesimal strain tensor

Derivation of the physical interpretation of the Lagrangian and Eulerian finite strain tensors

The stretch ratio for the differential element dX=dXNd\mathbf{X} = dX \mathbf{N}dX=dXN (Figure) in the direction of the unit vector N\mathbf{N}N at the material point PPP, in the undeformed configuration, is defined as Λ(N)=dxdX\Lambda_{( \mathbf{N} )} = \frac{dx}{dX}Λ(N)​=dXdx​ where dxdxdx is the deformed magnitude of the differential element dXd\mathbf{X}dX. Similarly, the stretch ratio for the differential element dx=dxnd\mathbf{x} = dx \mathbf{n}dx=dxn (Figure), in the direction of the unit vector n\mathbf{n}n at the material point ppp, in the deformed configuration, is defined as 1Λ(n)=dXdx\frac{1}{\Lambda_{( \mathbf{n} )}} = \frac{dX}{dx}Λ(n)​1​=dxdX​ The square of the stretch ratio is defined as Λ(N)2=(dxdX)2\Lambda_{( \mathbf{N} )}^{2} = \left( \frac{dx}{dX} \right)^{2}Λ(N)2​=(dXdx​)2 Knowing that (dx)2=CKLdXKdXL(dx)^{2} = C_{KL} dX_{K} dX_{L}(dx)2=CKL​dXK​dXL​ we have Λ(N)2=CKLNKNL\Lambda_{( \mathbf{N} )}^{2} = C_{KL} N_{K} N_{L}Λ(N)2​=CKL​NK​NL​ where NKN_{K}NK​ and NLN_{L}NL​ are unit vectors. The normal strain or engineering strain eNe_{\mathbf{N}}eN​ in any direction N\mathbf{N}N can be expressed as a function of the stretch ratio, e(N)=dx−dXdX=Λ(N)−1e_{( \mathbf{N} )} = \frac{dx - dX}{dX} = \Lambda_{( \mathbf{N} )} - 1e(N)​=dXdx−dX​=Λ(N)​−1 Thus, the normal strain in the direction I1\mathbf{I}_{1}I1​ at the material point PPP may be expressed in terms of the stretch ratio as e(I1)=dx1−dX1dX1=Λ(I1)−1=C11−1=δ11+2E11−1=1+2E11−1\begin{aligned} e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )} &= \frac{dx_{1} - dX_{1}}{dX_{1}} \\ &= \Lambda_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )} - 1 \\ &= \sqrt{C_{11}} - 1 = \sqrt{\delta_{11} + 2 E_{11}} - 1 \\ &= \sqrt{1 + 2 E_{11}} - 1 \end{aligned}e(I1​)​​=dX1​dx1​−dX1​​=Λ(I1​)​−1=C11​​−1=δ11​+2E11​​−1=1+2E11​​−1​ solving for E11E_{11}E11​ we have 2E11=(dx1)2−(dX1)2(dX1)2E11=(dx1−dX1dX1)+12(dx1−dX1dX1)2=e(I1)+12e(I1)2\begin{aligned} 2 E_{11} &= \frac{ (dx_{1})^{2} - (dX_{1})^{2} }{ (dX_{1})^{2} } \\ E_{11} &= \left( \frac{dx_{1} - dX_{1}}{dX_{1}} \right) + \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{dx_{1} - dX_{1}}{dX_{1}} \right)^{2} \\ &= e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )} + \frac{1}{2} e_{( \mathbf{I}_{1} )}^{2} \end{aligned}2E11​E11​​=(dX1​)2(dx1​)2−(dX1​)2​=(dX1​dx1​−dX1​​)+21​(dX1​dx1​−dX1​​)2=e(I1​)​+21​e(I1​)2​​ The shear strain , or change in angle between two line elements dX1d\mathbf{X}_{1}dX1​ and dX2d\mathbf{X}_{2}dX2​ initially perpendicular, and oriented in the principal directions I1\mathbf{I}_{1}I1​ and I2\mathbf{I}_{2}I2​, respectively, can also be expressed as a function of the stretch ratio. From the dot product between the deformed lines dx1d\mathbf{x}_{1}dx1​ and dx2d\mathbf{x}_{2}dx2​ we have dx1⋅dx2=dx1dx2cos⁡θ12F⋅dX1⋅F⋅dX2=dX1⋅FT⋅F⋅dX1⋅dX2⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2cos⁡θ12dX1⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2dX1dX2=dX1⋅FT⋅F⋅dX1⋅dX2⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2dX1dX2cos⁡θ12I1⋅C⋅I2=ΛI1ΛI2cos⁡θ12\begin{aligned} d\mathbf{x}_{1} \cdot d\mathbf{x}_{2} &= dx_{1} dx_{2} \cos \theta_{12} \\ \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{2} &= \sqrt{ d\mathbf{X}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{1} } \cdot \sqrt{ d\mathbf{X}_{2} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{2} } \cos \theta_{12} \\ \frac{ d\mathbf{X}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{2} }{ dX_{1} dX_{2} } &= \frac{ \sqrt{ d\mathbf{X}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{1} } \cdot \sqrt{ d\mathbf{X}_{2} \cdot \mathbf{F}^{T} \cdot \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{X}_{2} } }{ dX_{1} dX_{2} } \cos \theta_{12} \\ \mathbf{I}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{C} \cdot \mathbf{I}_{2} &= \Lambda_{\mathbf{I}_{1}} \Lambda_{\mathbf{I}_{2}} \cos \theta_{12} \end{aligned}dx1​⋅dx2​F⋅dX1​⋅F⋅dX2​dX1​dX2​dX1​⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2​​I1​⋅C⋅I2​​=dx1​dx2​cosθ12​=dX1​⋅FT⋅F⋅dX1​​⋅dX2​⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2​​cosθ12​=dX1​dX2​dX1​⋅FT⋅F⋅dX1​​⋅dX2​⋅FT⋅F⋅dX2​​​cosθ12​=ΛI1​​ΛI2​​cosθ12​​ where θ12\theta_{12}θ12​ is the angle between the lines dx1d\mathbf{x}_{1}dx1​ and dx2d\mathbf{x}_{2}dx2​ in the deformed configuration. Defining ϕ12\phi_{12}ϕ12​ as the shear strain or reduction in the angle between two line elements that were originally perpendicular, we have ϕ12=π2−θ12\phi_{12} = \frac{\pi}{2} - \theta_{12}ϕ12​=2π​−θ12​ thus, cos⁡θ12=sin⁡ϕ12\cos \theta_{12} = \sin \phi_{12}cosθ12​=sinϕ12​ then I1⋅C⋅I2=ΛI1ΛI2sin⁡ϕ12\mathbf{I}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{C} \cdot \mathbf{I}_{2} = \Lambda_{\mathbf{I}_{1}} \Lambda_{\mathbf{I}_{2}} \sin \phi_{12}I1​⋅C⋅I2​=ΛI1​​ΛI2​​sinϕ12​ or C12=C11C22sin⁡ϕ122E12+δ12=2E11+12E22+1sin⁡ϕ12E12=122E11+12E22+1sin⁡ϕ12\begin{aligned} C_{12} &= \sqrt{C_{11}} \sqrt{C_{22}} \sin \phi_{12} \\ 2 E_{12} + \delta_{12} &= \sqrt{2 E_{11} + 1} \sqrt{2 E_{22} + 1} \sin \phi_{12} \\ E_{12} &= \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 E_{11} + 1} \sqrt{2 E_{22} + 1} \sin \phi_{12} \end{aligned}C12​2E12​+δ12​E12​​=C11​​C22​​sinϕ12​=2E11​+1​2E22​+1​sinϕ12​=21​2E11​+1​2E22​+1​sinϕ12​​

Compatibility conditions

The problem of compatibility in continuum mechanics involves the determination of allowable single-valued continuous fields on bodies. These allowable conditions leave the body without unphysical gaps or overlaps after a deformation. Most such conditions apply to simply-connected bodies. Additional conditions are required for the internal boundaries of multiply connected bodies.

Compatibility of the deformation gradient

The necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of a compatible F\boldsymbol{F}F field over a simply connected body are ∇×F=0\boldsymbol{\nabla} \times \boldsymbol{F} = \boldsymbol{0}∇×F=0.

Compatibility of the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor

The necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of a compatible C\boldsymbol{C}C field over a simply connected body are R_{\alpha \beta \rho }^{\gamma } := \frac{\partial}{\partial X^{\rho}}[\,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\alpha \beta }^{\gamma }] - \frac{\partial}{\partial X^{\beta}}[\,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\alpha \rho }^{\gamma }] + \,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\mu \rho }^{\gamma }\,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\alpha \beta }^{\mu } - \,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\mu \beta }^{\gamma }\,_{(X)}\Gamma _{\alpha \rho }^{\mu } = 0 We can show these are the mixed components of the Riemann–Christoffel curvature tensor. Therefore, the necessary conditions for C\boldsymbol{C}C-compatibility are that the Riemann–Christoffel curvature of the deformation is zero.

Compatibility of the left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor

General sufficiency conditions for the left Cauchy–Green deformation tensor in three-dimensions were derived by Amit Acharya. Compatibility conditions for two-dimensional B\boldsymbol{B}B fields were found by Janet Blume.
